data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held in Room 4480, O'Neill House Office
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
M s . - Good afternoon, Mr. Still and everyone.
This is a deposition of Shawn Still conducted by the House Select Committee to
Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to House
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
And, counsel, could you please identify yourselves for the
Bob Driscoll from the McGlinchey firm, counsel to Mr. Still.
And Alfred Carry from McGlinchey for Shawn Still.
This will be a staff-led deposition, but members of the select committee may
choose to join us and may, of course, ask questions.
I'm an investigative counsel for the select committee.
joined here by my colleague,_, senior investigative counsel for the select
M s . - We also have a couple of other members of our select committee
who has just turned on his video.
M s . - - i s chief investigative counsel for our committee.
And, as you can see, you can see the participants on the screen here.
our chief clerk, on the line.
joined by any members of the committee, I'll do my best to note when they appear both
so that you know and for the record.
So some preliminaries to get through here before we get started.
Under the House deposition rules, neither committee members nor staff may
discuss the substance of testimony that you provide today unless the committee
You and your attorneys will have an opportunity to review the transcript.
And, before we begin, just want to go over a couple of deposition ground rules.
We will follow the House deposition rules that we provided to you with the
There is an official reporter here transcribing the record of the deposition.
As you noted before, we are recording this deposition.
recorded as well as the video here.
transcript that the official reporters take.
But the official record of the deposition is the
So to make that transcript as clean as possible, please wait until each question is
completed before you begin to speak your response, and we will also try to wait until
your responses are complete before asking any other questions.
The stenographers also cannot record nonverbal responses, like shaking your
head, so please answer your question with an audible verbal response.
And, of course, we're here today to ask you to provide complete answers based
If the question is not clear -- and I fully anticipate some of
mine will not be -- please don't hesitate to ask for clarification.
If you don't know the answer to any questions, please just say so.
You may only refuse to answer a question to preserve a privilege recognized by
If you refuse to answer a question based on a privilege, staff, we
may either proceed with the deposition or choose to seek a ruling from the chair on that
If the chair overrules an objection, you would be required to answer the
I do not have any reason to believe that we will be following that procedure today.
I also want to remind you that it is unlawful to deliberately provide false
Since this deposition will be under oath, providing false
information could result in criminal penalties for perjury or providing false statements.
Could you please stand, raise your right hand, and be sworn by the official
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalty of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
Logistically, we are going to try to make this as efficient as
But if at any time during the deposition you would like to take a break, please just let us
I don't expect that we're going to be here for a lengthy period this afternoon.
If you also have a question and you need to consult with your lawyers during the
deposition, that's, of course, absolutely fine, too.
brief sidebar in this room or, if you want to take a break off the record, you can go back to
the holding room and have a discussion there.
Any other questions or matters that you'd like to address, Mr. Driscoll, before we
As with the last deposition, I'm just going to preserve for
the record that we object to the authority of the committee to issue subpoenas based on
noncompliance with its authorizing statute and authorizing resolutions and to the extent
the question does not comply with the rules laid out by the committee for itself.
But, again, we just reserve those for the record, and we'll allow for this to go
forward in the same spirit as we did this morning.
Anything else before we get going?
Mr. Still, you have in front of you a binder of documents.
We have spoken to another one of the electors from Georgia, Mr. Shafer, this
I think the majority of these documents were produced by and relate more to
Mr. Shafer, so I don't want you to look at that binder and think that we will be here
talking about each one of these documents today.
But can we start by looking at the document behind tab 1, please?
Do you recognize what you're looking at there as the subpoena issued to you
And you are the person who is listed on the subpoena.
And do you understand that your appearance here today is pursuant
I'm going to ask you a few questions about the document collection
We received documents from your lawyers.
subpoena that you received from the select committee required you to produce
documents and information, including any electronically stored information.
And, of course, part of the
Did you search for records that are responsive to the subpoena as
set forth in the schedule attached to it?
Do you have a work and personal accounts?
Did you search your email accounts for any responsive information?
Do you have any other email addresses or accounts other than the one -- the work
I do for my personal, like, that I use just, like, for my Google backup, but
Did you search for any text messages that might have information responsive to
And did you locate any information -- any such responsive information?
What about hard-copy documents, did you search those for
I was never given any hard-copy documents for any of the work that we did
So is it fair to say that you didn't recall the existence of any
documents and, thus, didn't feel -- didn't need to go search for them?
There was no hard copy presented to me prior to and on the day of
Everything was in the meeting space.
What about any electronic versions of documents, like a Word or a
PDF document that would be stored on a computer, did you search for those?
Did you search on personal devices for responsive information, like a laptop or cell
I checked my cell phone, but there were no attachments, and there was no
text conversation with anyone pertaining to what we did other than when to appear.
Did you search any messaging applications on devices?
regular text messages, any applications like WhatsApp, Signal, Telegram?
I did check those, but the Signal group that I'm on doesn't have anything to
do with the electors, so there was nothing in there.
What about social media applications on any of your devices?
you search for potentially responsive information on, like, Facebook Messenger or
Twitter, direct messages, anything like that?
I didn't have Facebook at the time.
I only started a Facebook account a few
news sources, but there was nothing posted or received.
Mainly I just use it to follow
What about any handwritten or other hard-copy documents that
But my Twitter from that day was nothing.
Did you search for anything responsive to the subpoena?
I didn't have any notes taken on anything.
Did you coordinate or have any discussions with former members of
President Trump's campaign, the President's lawyers, or anyone at the RNC in responding
I don't know anybody at that level.
So did anyone, whether it's those or otherwise, affect or attempt to
influence the documents that you produced to the select committee?
And, wrapping up this conversation, have you produced to the select
committee all the documents and communications in your possession, custody, or control
that are responsive to the request in the subpoena?
So in the course of preparing for this deposition, was there anything
that you recalled that existed that you weren't able to find when you searched for
So can you just give us a couple of brief background facts about yourself?
I live in Johns Creek, Georgia.
I serve as the volunteer finance chairman for
I own a swimming pool construction company, so that's
candidacy 2 months ago for that, unrelated to anything else.
And I'm currently running for the Georgia State Legislature.
And you noted that you are a volunteer as the finance director for the Georgia
How long have you held that position?
About two and a half years.
meeting of the electors in December 2020?
How long have you lived in Georgia?
So you had that position at the time of the
So you were -- you're here because you were a Republican
elector in the 2020 election in Georgia.
Had you ever been a Presidential elector before?
How did you come to be a Republican elector in Georgia?
He asked me -- he appointed me to be the
finance chairman, and he asked me to be the secretary of our Presidential elector
delegation, because he knew that I knew most of the people that he had asked to be in
And do you remember around what time you became a Republican
I don't remember the exact day.
Let's look at the document behind tab No. 2, please.
So this looks like an email that was sent to you on March 3rd, 2020, 2:34 p.m.
Looks like an email from Stewart Bragg.
He was the executive director of the party.
working on a political campaign now full time.
So, in addition to yourself, there is another individual on the "to"
So what do you remember about this email?
He left the party, and he's
I assume that it relates to what you
were just describing as the process of becoming a Presidential elector.
I just --1 know Stewart very well from working with him.
assume, sent this email to everybody else that was an elector.
If you look at the body of the email, the second sentence, Mr. Bragg
writes, "Please let me know if you will not be able to submit the form at the Capital
during qualifying in person, as it will have to be notarized prior to myself or anyone else
What do you remember about the process it sounds like that occurred in person
at the capitol of qualifying as a Presidential elector?
The qualifying process was at the same time that we were doing qualifying
for other political candidates, so a room not dissimilar from this.
to run for State rep or State senate, the electors came in and had to present and submit
their document in the same manner and fashion.
And so, just as anyone was doing their filing paperwork
If you turn to the next tab, tab No. 3, this is a blank document, but it's
the document that was attached to the email that we were just looking at.
Does this look familiar to you?
Is this the document that you were required to complete and submit
If I could direct your attention to -- there is a paragraph maybe
two-thirds of the way down that's the wordiest part of the document.
have never been convicted and sentenced."
What's your understanding of the obligations incurred or, you know, the
meaning of signing on, that, you know, sort of attesting to this document?
Just that I wasn't a felon and that I was in good standing as a citizen of
Georgia, but not that there was anything further about it.
And is it -- my understanding correct that this is the -- this is a
candidacy affidavit that is completed by Presidential electors as well as other candidates
So, earlier, you recalled that Mr. Shafer suggested that you would
be -- to become a Presidential elector and specifically asked you to serve as secretary of
The duties were just to verify -- to try to help staff verify who all the
So what was your understanding of the duties of the secretary's
members were, because Chairman Shafer didn't know all 16 of the people, and neither
they were before we admitted them into the room.
But at least it allowed me to make sure that I was able to, face to face, verify who
So you had a role to play at the in-person qualification ceremony?
So when the -- not when we're talking about naming
electors, but, rather, making sure that the right people are the ones who are actually
Did you have any role in helping to prepare paperwork or maintaining minutes or
And was it Mr. Shafer who gave you the understanding of what the
What kind of communications did you have with Mr. Sinners
I think it was -- from March until December, I think we maybe had three
The other person was Robert Sinners, who is head of election
about -- either generally about being an elector, or specifically about being the secretary?
day operations and worked for the Trump campaign.
And do you remember -- was Mr. Sinners involved at the early stage
here of -- in March -- of identifying the people who would serve as Republican elector?
I think, you know, by midsummer he was involved.
And so I think you said you remembered maybe three conversations
Were any of those specific to your role as secretary?
I think we can put a pin in that and talk about Mr. Sinners when we
get chronologically up to the December -- a little bit closer to the December 14th date.
Can I ask you to turn to the next tab, No. 4, please?
This is an email and sent by David Shafer.
Do you know who the group of individuals who are the recipients of this email
Largely party activists, people that just either had been involved in the
Georgia Republican Party or people who were maybe recommended to us by the Trump
campaign as having been particularly vocal about the campaign and promoting Trump
A couple of those people ended up being disqualified off of this list, which is why
this is the initial, but this is not the final list of people.
Just to be clear, are you talking about the list of people going down
Mr. Driscoll. -- or the list of addressees?
The list of people going vertically.
So the list of names vertically in this document, are these the individuals that
you understood to be the qualified Republican Presidential electors as of March 5th?
And, just generally speaking, I think I heard you to describe them as
people that were involved in the party or were otherwise recommended by the Trump
Twelve of the 16 I know very well.
How well did you know the individuals on this list?
So, after the process of determining who will serve as a Republican
elector in Georgia, what communications did you have with these individuals or with
Mr. Shafer between March 5th and election day?
Very little about this role, because we just -- we were excited to be part of
history and thought it was kind of a neat novelty thing to do.
were just looking forward to getting called in to fulfill the duty as a nominee, as an
And, in March, or in the early time period there before election day,
generally what was your understanding of the duties of a Presidential elector in Georgia?
Just no different than I had learned in civics class as a kid, that, you know,
you're going to go in and, at the prescribed day and time, that you're going to go in and
fill out the paperwork and take an oath that you're casting your vote for whoever the
winner was based on the election outcome.
And did you have any understanding of how the winner of the
Presidential election was to be determined in Georgia?
Other than popular vote, or -- right.
Yeah, you referred in your description of the role of a
Presidential elector that, once the winner was determined, I think, then you would have a
And my understanding -- my question is just, what was your understanding
of how that winner is determined under Georgia law?
As every other State, that it's based on popular vote.
So when did you first hear about the possibility of casting electoral votes for
Donald Trump as candidate for President of the United States, even if he lost the popular
vote in the State of Georgia?
It wasn't until after the election.
So no discussion of the possibility of an alternate slate of electors before election
That was going to be my next question.
There is an article that was published before the election actually
end of September 2020 in The Atlantic by a reporter named Barton Gellman that
addressed the possibility of an alternate slate of electors.
were discussions that were occurring by -- within the Trump campaign or the Republican
Party about testing the assumption that electors would be chosen by popular vote.
It sort of suggested that there
Were you aware of that before election day at all?
What about in other experience that you may have had in the Republican Party in
Did you later come to be aware of that article or any of the
I can't say that I've ever read an article from The Atlantic.
Have you ever heard of the concept of an alternate slate of electors meeting?
Not until probably mid-November, mid to late November, when we were still
very tumultuous about the election results.
So we'll come back to that.
In -- well, actually, go ahead, why don't you tell me, what did you understand
when you came to have this -- when somebody raised the issue?
to think that this was a possibility in mid to late November?
We just knew that the election results were very much in question, and
there was enough evidence to want to continue investigating further the election
So we knew that the electoral college or the Presidential electors had to meet at a
certain day and time, so we were trying to get through all of the recounts and
And so the only discussion was, if we had to preserve the integrity of those
lawsuits, that we were told by counsel that it was possible that we would have to cast the
ballots in the same manner and fashion as if he had won so that there had been two sets
of ballots and that it could be substituted if needed, but only in the event of an overturn
of the ballots as they were, because the number kept changing.
So you used the term "we" a couple of times there.
Well, being on the executive committee for the Georgia Republican
Party -- several of those members are on that list on exhibit 4 -- so it was with them.
It was with obviously Chairman Shafer.
And I think we'll talk a little bit more about some of those
But let me just ask you, at that time when -- in mid to late November that we're
referring to, were you aware of any other planning that was being done about convening
alternate slates of electors in other States?
So your knowledge was specific to Georgia?
And I think you've just generally addressed this, but what was your
understanding of why it was necessary to convene as Republican electors on
Specifically, because our ballot count was changing, because we felt like
there was enough evidence to be within a very tight margin of error, that if in some
recount, whether it was signature verification, if it was scanning the ballots, or whatever
the issue was, that when you're talking a fraction of a percent difference, we wanted to
make sure that, because we couldn't meet at a later date, if we had not met, then the
President's lawsuit would not have had any merit and could not have been overturned if
the election results had been overturned.
It was explained to me like this.
It's like, when you have the Super Bowl, you
print T-shirts, both teams as being the winner, and you keep the T-shirts for the ones that
were the winner, and you throw away the ones that weren't, but you still have to have
two sets of T-shirts for both sets of winners.
Just a friend of the family when I was asking, like, how does this work?
A friend of -- a personal friend of yours?
A personal friend outside of all of it.
So who explained it to you that way?
Is that person involved at all in --
Or a lawyer giving you advice?
I was trying to explain -- it was actually just a -- it was spoken of loosely back
in December of '20, but that description I just gave you actually just came to me a few
weeks ago in the example of the Super Bowl because it just occurred.
The question was, what do you do with the Bengals T-shirts?
You can't do anything else with them.
destroy those T-shirts that say that somebody else won the Super Bowl.
In the same manner, it was explained to us, the electors, that we were only doing
this to preserve that possibility of, if it had been overturned, that these would have then
replaced the Biden elector ballots, and that was it.
Let me go back and unpack that a little bit with you,
ask you a couple of follow-up questions, okay?
So you were just -- you just referred to lawyers, I believe, explaining to you the
purpose of meeting as Republican electors in December of 2020.
Who are the lawyers that you recall explaining that to you?
Brad Carver, who is one of the people on this list; Alex Kaufman; and the
other -- the only two other people that I spoke to about it were Sinners and Shafer?
Brad Carver is a member of the Georgia GOP Executive Committee.
one of our congressional district chairs.
He's an election law attorney, and so very well
We may address this a little bit later, but I'm aware that you were a
Did any of those lawyers represent you in that lawsuit?
They're the ones that asked me to add my name, because I had higher
standing than the gentleman who had initially filed the lawsuit, so to give it more
credence in the court they just asked me to attach my name to it with that.
So it was -- the lawsuit was filed in a different county than the one I live in, but, in
order to -- they needed a Presidential elector's name attached to it.
Was Mr. Carver also involved in that, representing you in that
So, without asking about any communications that you had with
Mr. Kaufman or Mr. Carver in the other circumstance, right, any potentially privileged
advice that they gave to you, but just specific to communications that you had with them
about the role of Presidential electors, do you -- about how many conversations did you
And is that -- were they on the phone with you together or separate,
I think twice with Kaufman and once with Carver.
There wasn't a long walk-through process on that.
And about what timeframe do you recall those conversations taking
The lawsuit that my name was attached to is on December, I think, 20th, so
So you recall these conversations happening after the meeting of
The idea about me joining that lawsuit in Coffee County didn't
happen until after we had met as electors.
Did you have any conversations with either Mr. Carver or Mr. Kaufman before
December 14th about the purpose of the meeting of Republican electors?
So when you gave us the Super Bowl analogy as a means of remembering what
your understanding was of the purpose of the meeting of the electors, were there any
other communications you had that gave you that understanding?
talked to that helped you to understand that that was the purpose?
M r . - So if I could just clarify?
Because I heard the testimony I think the same way-did.
gave the analogy of the Super Bowl, which I know you said came up much later, recently,
you said that your understanding of the elector situation was exactly the same, and the
lawyers had explained to you, and then you went on to state what they explained.
Was that -- I think that's why she was circling back, to see if those were the
lawyers who had explained that to you.
The explanation just that we were trying to preserve the integrity of the
lawsuit and that we had to just fill out the paperwork the same way, so that it wouldn't
moot the lawsuit that was still pending by the President.
That's just what -- I'm a simple pool builder, right?
the exact code of where that was coming from.
So they just were saying that, in order
to preserve this, we're filling it out the exact same way, and that's all we were told.
And so Sinners, Shafer were getting, I guess, their direction from Kaufman and
But we all know each other through so many different levels, it was -- I think it's
hard to kind of segregate exactly when each conversation happened.
But it was a very consistent message that we were told throughout all of that, is
this is the only reason why we're doing this, is to preserve the integrity of being able to
So it sounds like you talked to Shafer and Sinners about the concept?
And they may have recounted to you what they had heard from lawyers?
You didn't specifically -- or you don't specifically recall talking to lawyers
I did not seek independent legal advice on this.
I think that clarifies the confusion in my mind.
We made -- this may become relevant again later, but going back to
your Super Bowl analogy where you were thinking about what happens to the loser, the
T-shirts that showed that the loser actually won the Super Bowl, I think you suggested
that those T-shirts are destroyed once the outcome of the Super Bowl is determined.
Do you remember having similar conversations with anyone about the votes that
were cast by the Republican electors in Georgia, that they would be destroyed or set
aside if the election contest suit had not gone the way you -A
When we met and when we signed the documents, Robert Sinners printed
them in the room at the capitol.
We signed them at the capitol.
And then he packaged them up and said that he was sending them to D.C., to the
And I remember specifically asking him what happens to them if there is not an
And he said, "Well, that's not up to me to decide, but I guess we'll just set
them aside and box them up somewhere, and that'll be the end of it."
That was what Mr. Sinners responded when you asked that
And, when he said, "I guess they'll just box them up," what was your
sense of who he was referring to?
I assumed that he meant somebody that dealt with Federal election.
guess there is a department or a unit somewhere here that deals with that.
But I think you said that Mr. Sinners collected the documents and
that he was immediately going to send them to D.C.
So was there any suggestion that they would only be sent to D.C. later, in the
event that there was an outcome of the election to contest litigation?
So, earlier, when we were talking about the context of the meeting,
you referred to the fact that you believed that the election results were very much in
Let me ask you a couple of questions.
belabor the timeline in any way.
But let's talk a little bit about what happened from
November 3rd, election day, up to the meeting of the electors on December 14th.
So did you have any official role on election day?
And, just generally speaking, what were your impressions of how election
day went in Georgia on November 3rd, 2020?
We had countless numbers of reports of
people -- because I had no official capacity, but I was trying to help coordinate people to
And so trying to find volunteers, making sure they could get into poll
But then we were hearing from the poll watch volunteers they were being blocked
out, that they were locked out of buildings, not permitted to see anything, they were
pushed aside, that -- I don't know if you all saw the footage, but of the head of
the -- Fulton County is the largest county in Georgia, and the director of elections pulls
out two large suitcases full of ballots mysteriously under a paper -- or under a
table -- when no one else is looking.
stress and questions on the outcome.
It just -- it presented a tremendous amount of
And so we felt, "we" being those of us who were electors, but just, I think,
Republicans in general were very skeptical of what was happening.
begging and demanding answers and investigations into the irregularities with how
So you said -- you referred to "we", and the one sense of the "we" was electors.
A couple of follow-ups for you.
So did you have communications with other members of the individuals actually who are
still in front of you on that list of the Republican electors for President in Georgia?
So Joseph Brannan is our treasurer.
So I remember talking to him a little bit about it.
Daryl Moody is chairman of our Georgia Republican Foundation and a neighbor, so
But people who had nothing to do with anything in the party, just concerned
citizens, were really upset about it.
many efforts had been made to try to get to the bottom of the irregularities.
And from election day until December 14th, so
And I think that's why the number kept changing.
the votes, every time they'd look back at signature verification, it just -- there was always
some discrepancy, sometimes in the hundreds, sometimes in the thousands of ballots,
but every time that someone was looking at it.
And so people were just very, very concerned.
And so we knew that lawsuits
were coming, and we knew that we wanted to make sure that we had done our part, our
very, very small part in all this, to at least make sure that, if there had been an overturn in
the election results -- we were told that, if the election results had been overturned and
we had not met and not filled out the paperwork exactly the way it was, that the overturn
wouldn't have happened because we had not met.
And that was made crystal clear to us.
But that was -- is it fair that those -- your understanding of the role
that you might have to play as an elector came later and wasn't in your mind on election
But over the course of those 6 weeks, that's -- the progression led to that,
that in the week of December 14th, we just felt like there is a really good chance this
And you mentioned that you had -- you were playing a role in help
Had you ever done that in a Presidential election before?
I've been a precinct captain in my local area just for yard signs and door
I assume that's on behalf of the Republican Party of
I had never coordinated poll watchers.
And you specifically recalled the -- an incident in Fulton County.
think you referred to somebody saying something.
This is the suitcases of ballots under a table.
I saw it on the evening news.
Did you have any direct interaction with poll watchers in Fulton County about that
How did you come to understand those -- that fact pattern?
So just to again run through a little bit of the timeline of the election
after November 3rd, election day itself, is it consistent with your recollection that it took
many days for ballots to be counted in Georgia following the Presidential election?
And do you remember -- generally speaking, give us your
When did you feel that the counting and the results had been determined?
It was -- there are still lingering to this day many unanswered questions
But once President Biden was sworn in, we've let a lot of that go.
But, speaking as someone who is currently running for the State legislature, the
only thing people want to talk about, even today, as recently as this past weekend, is
what am I going to do, if elected, what's the number one thing I'm going to do to try to
make sure that elections are safe and secure in Georgia, because no Republican primary
voter believes that it was accurate and fair.
You also described, I can't remember the exact words that you said, but
investigations or, rather, audits that have been done about the result.
Were you referring to audits and recounts that were done by the secretary of
And, generally speaking, before the meeting of electors on
December 14th, what was your understanding of the results of those audits insofar as
who had been determined by the secretary of state's office to be the winner of the
So bigger answer to that question, what the secretary of state's office was
doing was rescanning the same ballots through the same machines, and then trying to
demonstrate that there may or may not be a different result, but they weren't actually
doing an investigation on the bigger picture of it.
All they were trying to say and do -- and I know Raffensperger very well.
trying to save face in all of this.
audit, but he's just running the same ballots through the same machines and then sitting
back and saying, "See, everything was normal."
But there was never an investigation on the thousands and thousands of absentee
So that he would just say that he was conducting an
There was no investigation on the 6.8 million absentee ballots that were mailed
There was no checking on the signature-match verification.
There were just so many other questions regarding how they were conducting the
audits that every time they did another audit and tried to say, "Look, same result," it
just -- it created such a fury with people that were asking them to please look at this in a
So long answer to your question, but I think it's important for you all to
understand the context of what was in everyone's mind at the time, is that it felt like
there was fraud, it felt like there was a cover-up.
weren't trying to do anything other than get to the bottom of, what's the real number?
And we were really just trying to -- we
So leaving that topic, unless you have anything,-that you'd like
11111'11 pause and see if there is anything you'd like to ask?
We will interpret that as a no.
So you told us a little bit earlier about how you heard that there would be a
Let's talk a little bit more specifics about December 14th, if that's
Do you remember how far in advance before December 14th you heard that you
It was a couple of weeks beforehand.
didn't have phone numbers on all these people.
help him track down some folks.
Robert Sinners called me because he
He asked me who I knew and if I could
So I don't remember, we'd have to look back through, but, I mean, I'm sure there
is some correspondence of when that call was made.
tell people when and where to be.
